{{infobox character | people-duplicated = [[Men|Man]] | people = [[Pre-Númenóreans|Man of Agar]] | name=Hazad Longbeard | image= | caption= | pronun= | othernames=Blear-eyed carl (by [[Mogru]]), Hazad uBuldar (by [[Mogru]]), Tal-argan Longbeard | titles= | position= | location=[[Agar]] | affiliation=[[Pre-Númenóreans|Folk of Agar]] | language=[[Pre-Númenórean|Pre-Númenórean language]] | birth=[[Second Age]] | birthlocation=[[Agar]] | rule= | death=[[Second Age]] | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor= | house= | parentage=[[Buldar]] and [[Elmar]] | siblings= | spouse= | children=Sixteen unnamed sons,{{PM|Elmar}} [[Tal-Elmar (character)|Tal-Elmar]] | gender=Male | height=Short | hair=Long-bearded | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Hazad Longbeard''' was a [[Pre-Númenóreans|Man]] of [[Agar]] who was the son of [[Buldar]] and [[Elmar]] during the [[Second Age]].The exact timeframe of Hazad's and Tal-Elmar's life is not given, but since the [[Númenóreans]] are seen as hostiles in the story, it's possible that it refers to a time after the [[Shadow]] fell over the Island, when they started to dominate the natives of [[Middle-earth]]; this points to a date around {{SA|1800}}. See {{App|SA}} == History == Hazad was described in his youth as being "broad, swarthy, short, though, harsh-tongued, heavy-handed, and quick to violence." {{PM|Elmar}} Hazad’s sons are said to resemble him in his youth. Though he found pride in the number of his descendants, his greatest joy was his beard, long over five feet and, unlike his sons, soft, “ruly to his hand,” and close to him all the time. Hazad married late, due to the admiration he had for his late mother, Elmar. He fathered many children, including [[Tal-Elmar (character)|Tal-Elmar]], who was his seventeenth child. Along with his youngest son, he delivered the ill message to [[Mogru]] of [[Númenóreans|Númenórean]] ships approaching the Hills of Agar. == Etymology == Some analysts have noticed the similarity of ''Hazad'' with [[Khuzdul|Dwarvish]] ''[[Khazâd]]'', "Dwarves", and [[Adûnaic]] ''hazad'', "seven".
